Why some women cross the finish line ahead of men
 
RECRUITMENT
The course is tougher but women are staying the distance, reports Andrew Crisp.

consultants NB Selection, shows that while one in six men who appear on interview shortlists g
figure rises to one in four for women.
B The study concentrated on applications for management positions in the $45,000 to $110,000 s
and found that women are more successful than men in both the private and public sectors Dr E

D Managerial and executive progress made by women is confirmed by the annual survey of board
carried out by Korn/Ferry/Carre/ Orban International. This year the survey shows a doubling of 
women serving as non-executive directors compared with the previous year. However, progress
painfully slow and there were still only 18 posts filled by women out of a total of 354 nonexecuti

F  In business as a whole, there are a number of factors encouraging the prospect of greater equ

increasing. In addition a far greater number of women are now passing through higher educatio
them better qualified to move into management positions.
GOrganisations such as the European Women’s Management Development Network provide a r
opportunities for women to enhance their skills and contacts. Through a series of both pan-Euro
